title: CFO Change at Campbell Soup Follows an Expected Pattern
text:
Campbell Soup Co. ’s move to replace its finance chief follows an expected pattern in which new a chief executive selects his or her own finance chief to execute a strategy.

The Camden, N.J.-based soup and snacks maker, on Thursday named Mick Beekhuizen its next chief financial officer, effective Sept. 30. His appointment comes about seven months after the company’s new Chief Executive Mark Clouse took over in late January.

Mr. Beekhuizen, the finance leader of yogurt maker Chobani LLC, replaces Anthony DiSilvestro, who has served in the role since 2014.

Analysts and recruiters said they expected the company to appoint a new CFO less than a year into the tenure of the new CEO.

“New CEOs really want their partner,” said Peter Crist, the chairman of executive recruitment firm Crist|Kolder Associates.

Kraft Heinz Co. , which in June got a new chief executive, on Monday appointed a new finance chief. Kellogg Co. appointed a new CFO in May, about 19 months into the tenure of Chief Executive Steven A. Cahillane. And Mondelez International Inc. took less than a year to name a new finance head after CEO Dirk Van de Put took over in November 2017.

The bond between a company’s chief executive and its finance chief is crucial, especially at companies dealing with a range of challenges such as Campbell, Mr. Crist said. “If those two people don’t feel good about each other, there will be a change,” he said.

Campbell didn't immediately respond to a request for comment.

In a press release Thursday, Mr. Clouse, the CEO, praised Mr. DiSilvestro, the CFO who is leaving the company on Oct. 15. “Anthony has been a strong leader during his Campbell career and a valuable partner during my first seven months with the company,” he said.

Campbell faces shifting consumer tastes toward products perceived as fresher and growing competition from store-brand products developed by retailers. The company is expected to report financial results for its fiscal fourth quarter on Friday.

Chief executives and finance chiefs must share a vision for the company’s strategy to succeed, said Cathy Logue, a managing director at executive search firm Stanton Chase. “They have to work hand in glove,” she said.

Mr. Beekhuizen is expected to help bring down the company’s debt level as well as finding around $315 million in cost savings as part of a $850 million cost reduction effort to be completed in fiscal 2022, analysts said.

Campbell had $9.1 billion in net debt at the end of its fiscal third quarter, down from $9.7 billion at the end of fiscal 2018, according to S&P Capital IQ. The company’s debt spiked following the $6.1 billion acquisition of Snyder’s-Lance in late 2017.

The company also needs to ramp up investments in its soup business, said Diane Shand, a senior director at S&P Global Ratings. Mr. Beekhuizen will have to convince investors that he can run the finances at a much larger company than Chobani, she said.

—Micah Maidenberg contributed to this article.

Write to Nina Trentmann at Nina.Trentmann@wsj.com
